Fig 6 Multifunctional interlayer with simultaneously capturing and catalytically converting polysulfides for boosting safety and performance of lithium-sulfur batteries at high-low temperatures Xiao-Shuan Chen You Gao Guo-Rui Zhu Hui-Jun Chen Si-Chong Chen Xiu-Li Wang Gang Wu ⁎ Yu-Zhong Wang Collaborative Innovation Center for Eco-Friendly and Fire-Safety Polymeric Materials (MoE), State Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials Engineering, National Engineering Laboratory of Eco-Friendly Polymeric Materials (Sichuan), College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610064, Sichuan, China Collaborative Innovation Center for Eco-Friendly and Fire-Safety Polymeric Materials (MoE) State Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials Engineering National Engineering Laboratory of Eco-Friendly Polymeric Materials (Sichuan) College of Chemistry Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610064 China Collaborative Innovation Center for Eco-Friendly and Fire-Safety Polymeric Materials (MoE), State Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials Engineering, National Engineering Laboratory of Eco-Friendly Polymeric Materials (Sichuan), College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610064, Sichuan, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries as extremely promising high-density energy storage devices have attracted extensive concern. However, practical applications of Li-S batteries are severely restricted by not only intrinsic polysulfides shuttle resulting from their concentration gradient diffusion and sluggish conversion kinetics but also serious safety issue caused by thermolabile and combustible polymer separators. Herein, it is presented for the first time that a robust and multifunctional separator with urchin-like Co-doped FeOOH microspheres and multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) as an interlayer simultaneously achieves to suppress polysulfides shuttle as well as improves thermotolerance and nonflammability of commercial PP separator. Accordingly, Li-S batteries with modified separator exhibit remarkable performance in a wide range temperatures of -25–100 °C. Typically, under 25 °C, ultrahigh initial capacities of 1441 and 827.29 mA h g−1 at 1 C and 2 C are delivered, and remained capacities of 936 and 663.18 mA h g−1 can be obtained after 500 cycles, respectively. At 0.1 C, the S utilization can reach up to 97%. Significantly, at 1 C, the batteries also deliver an excellent performance with remained capacities of high to 862.3, 608.4 and 420.6 mA h g−1 after 100, 300 and 450 cycles under 75, 0 and -25 °C, respectively. This work provides a new insight for developing stable and safe high-performance Li-S batteries. Graphical abstract Urchin-like Co-FeOOH microspheres with capturing and catalyzing polysulfides are prepared. Microspheres and MWCNTs as multifunctional interlayer introduced on commercial PP separator endow Li-S battery with superior performance in the range of -25–100 °C. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries High-low temperature performances Hierarchically urchin-like microspheres Multifunctional interlayer Capturing and converting polysulfides 1 Introduction With the serious crisis of energy and environment, the request for environmentally friendly and naturally abundant materials in energy storage is continuously increasing in the world [1]. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery with superhigh theoretical capacity of 1672 mA h g−1 and theoretical energy density of 2600 Wh kg−1 has raised widespread concern owing to the abundant, low-cost and environment-friendly active material of cathode, i.e. sulfur [2]. However, the Li-S battery inherently possesses some serious drawbacks, typically a low actual energy density, a poor capacity retention, and a low coulombic efficiency due to i) the low sulfur utilization resulting from an insulating nature of sulfur and its reduced products (Li2S2/Li2S), ii) the destruction of cathode structure generated by an irreversible volume change of sulfur and Li2S, and iii) the shuttle effect of soluble lithium polysulfides (LiPSs, Li2S x, x ≥ 4) in electrolyte during charge-discharge process [3,4]. In terms of the shuttle effect, one of the most representative strategies is combined the sulfur with different host materials [5–14]. Although the excellent electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries has been achieved, the preparing strategies of the host materials are complicated and expensive. Recently, a facile and low-cost approach, i.e. coating functional materials on a commercial polypropylene (PP) separator as polysulfide-blocked/anchored interlayers, has widely been introduced to resolve this problem. Although considerable progresses have been achieved for suppressing the shuttle effect by the modified PP separators with physical barrier or/and chemical bonding functions [15–21], an intrinsic slow reaction kinetics of polysulfides conversion can continually contribute to the shuttle effect. Recently, some works have confirmed that employing catalytic materials as the interlayers can facilitate the conversion of polysulfides into short chain lithium sulfides, thus reducing the shuttle of polysulfides as well as improving the reaction kinetics of the electrode [22]. Zhang et al. prepared the P-doped BN nanosheets decorated graphene as a functional interlayer, and a retained capacity of 728.7 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at 1.0 C was obtained [23]. Jiao et al. designed a TiO2−MXene heterostructures-based separator to catalyze polysulfides conversion, and a good cycling stability with an initial discharge capacity of 800 mA h g−1 and an average capacity fading rate of 0.028% per cycle for 1000 cycles at 2 C was achieved [24]. Yuan et al. reported a conductive and catalytic triple-phase interfaces to enable the uniform nucleation in high-rate Li-S batteries with an initial capacity of 916 mA h g−1 and a capacity retention of 459 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at 6.0 C [25]. Although the electrochemical performance of the Li-S batteries with these catalytic materials have made a great improvement, an expensive and tanglesome preparation processes of the catalytic materials also bought a challenge in practical application. Recently, Hong et al. designed a cerium based metal-organic frameworks as an efficient separator coating to catalyze the conversion of polysulfides for high performance Li-S batteries by a simple method [26]. However, the adsorption ability of the catalytic materials for polysulfides are usually limited [27]. Therefore, it is highly desired and still extremely challenging for developing an ideal functional interlayer which simultaneously possesses strong physical/chemical adsorptions to anchor polysulfides, rapid electron-lithium ion pathways to reuse the anchored polysulfides, and abundant catalytic sites to accelerate the reaction kinetics of polysulfides through a facile and low-cost preparation strategy. In addition, due to the flammability and/or thermal instability of sulfur, organic electrolytes, organic separators, and lithium metal, the severe safety issues, especially combustion and short-circuiting explosion, significantly restrict the practical applications of Li-S battery. Up to now, some considerable efforts, such as adding flame retardant into electrolytes or cathode [28,29], using an intrinsic flame-retardant organic electrolyte [30], and preparing nonflammable separator [31], have been made for overcoming the combustion problem. Although it is helpful for reducing the flammability, there is still a safety risk of battery, especially the short circuit inside the battery resulting from the thermal deformation of organic separators at a high operating temperature or the protruding dendrite of lithium metal. Furthermore, many electronic apparatuses including electric vehicles (EVs) and hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs) need to work in a wide range of temperatures from high to low temperatures [32,33]. Unfortunately, these previously reported researches were mainly implemented at room temperature, and focusing on the safety and stability of Li-S battery at both low and high temperatures is still very incipient [34]. In particular, it is extremely rare to develop the advanced Li-S batteries with ultrahigh capacity, excellent rate performance and outstanding cycling life in a wide temperature range through the easily prepared multifunctional interlayers. Herein, by a facile and low-cost vacuum filtration on a commercial PP separator, hierarchically urchin-like Co-doped FeOOH (Co-FeOOH) microspheres and multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) are introduced as an interlayer to rationally construct a multifunctional separator (Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP) for the first time. As shown in Scheme 1 , such the interlayer plays the following roles: (1) a physical barrier layer for impeding the polysulfides migration; (2) a hierarchically porous structure with large surface area for physically adsorbing polysulfides and storing electrolyte; (3) diversely doped atoms and hydroxy groups for chemically capturing polysulfides and suppressing PP combustion [35,36]; (4) abundant catalytic sites for facilitating redox kinetics of sulfur electrochemistry; (5) a 3D conductive network for ensuring unimpeded Li-ion/electron transport. With those functions, the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator endows the Li-S battery with highly safety and extraordinary electrochemical performance. Concretely, under 25 °C at 1 C, an ultrahigh initial discharge capacity of 1441 mA h g−1 is delivered, and the capacity of 936 mA h g−1 can be remained after 500 cycles. Even at 2 C, the battery still releases an initial capacity of 827.29 mA h g−1 and a remained capacity of 663.18 mA h g−1 with a capacity fading rate of 0.04% cycle−1 after 500 cycles. At 0.1 C, the S utilization can reach up to 97%. More importantly, at high C-rate, the outstanding performance of Li-S battery at extreme high- and low-temperatures is realized (862.3, 608.4 and 420.6 mA h g−1 after 100, 300 and 450 cycles at 1 C under 75, 0 and −25 °C, respectively), which is hardly reported in the previous studies. By comparison in Table S1 (Supporting Information), the performance of our batteries is superior to the state-of-the-art results released in the literatures involving the modified separators. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials FeCl3·6H2O and multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) were purchased from J&K Scientific. 1,3-dioxacyclopentane (DOL) and CoCl2·6H2O were offered by Sigma-Aldrich. 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) was provided by TCI. Li2S and S powder were purchased from Alfa. Na2SO4 was supplied by Aladdin. The electrolyte with 1.0 M lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) and 1 wt% LiNO3 in DOL/DME (1:1 by volume), polyvinylidenefluoride (PVDF), Super P, polypropylene (PP) separator (Celgard 2500), and CR2032 coin cells were bought from 4slaboratory. Aluminum foil, lithium plates were obtained from Shenzhen Kejing Star Technology Co., Ltd. N-Methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) and C2H5OH were provided by Kelong Reagent Corp. All the reagents were analytical pure and used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of Co-FeOOH microspheres Co-FeOOH microspheres were prepared by a hydrothermal synthesis. In the first instance, a mixture of FeCl3·6H2O (3 mmol), CoCl2·6H2O (1 mmol), and Na2SO4 (4.4 mmol) were dissolved in 90 mL deionized water. Then the solution was stirred at room temperature for 30 min and a saffron and transparent was obtained. In the end, the above-mentioned solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 6 h. After cooling down to room temperature, saffron product was obtained and washed by deionized water for three times. Then the product was dried at 60 °C for 12 h in a vacuum oven. 2.3 Preparation of Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs /PP separator Firstly, 5 mg PVDF was dissolved in 210 mL mixed solvent of NMP/C2H5OH (1/6, v/v). Afterwards, 20 mg as-prepared Co-FeOOH microspheres and 25 mg MWCNTs were added to the solution, then the suspension was dispersed by ultrasonication for 4 h in ice bath. Finally, a uniform dispersion was obtained and deposited onto one side of commercial PP membrane (Celgard 2500) via vacuum filtration. Then the as-prepared separator was oven-dried at 60 °C for 12 h in vacuum and punched into discs with a diameter of 19 mm. The areal density of the interlayer is about 0.6 mg cm−2. The MWCNTs/PP separator was prepared by a similar process without the addition of Co-FeOOH microspheres. 2.4 Preparation of pure S cathode Super-P/sulfur (SP/S) composite was prepared by mixing S, SP and PVDF (7:2:1 by weight) in N-methyl-2-pyrolidone (NMP) to form a homogeneous slurry. The slurry was then uniformly coated on the surface of the Al current collector and dried at 60 °C for 12 h in a vacuum oven to remove the NMP. Then the coated Al foil was punched into pieces 12 mm in diameter. The actual sulfur loading is about 1.0–1.2 mg cm−2, the sulfur content in the SP/S composite was estimated by the thermogravimetric analyses (TGA). 2.5 Electrochemical test at room temperature The batteries were assembled in an Ar-filled glovebox (LS-750S, Chengdu Dellix Slovak Industrial Co. Ltd.). SP/S, lithium foil and 40 µL organic solvent included 1 M LiTFSI and 1 wt% LiNO3 in 1/1 (v/v) 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) and 1,3-dioxacyclopentane (DOL) were used as cathode, anode and electrolyte, severally. The Galvanostatic discharge/charge was measured by a Neware BTS-610 battery test system (China) with a voltage window of 1.7–2.8 V. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) curves were tested by a PARSTAT multichannel electrochemical workstation (Princeton Applied Research, USA). 2.6 Electrochemical test at −25 °C and 100 °C In detail, the batteries packaged in the Zip-lock bags were connected with the Neware BTS-610 battery test system by the testing wires firstly, and then the above encapsulated batteries were placed in a cryostat/heater and tested at −25 °C/100 °C (the test procedure was consistent with room temperature). 2.7 Preparation of 5 mM Li2S8 solution The polysulfides solution was prepared by controlling the stoichiometric ratio of sulfur and Li2S to 7:1. The Li2S and sulfur powder were dissolved in a mixed solution of DOL/DME (1:1 in volume), and then the mixture was stirred strongly at 55 °C for 48 h in an Ar-filled glovebox. Finally, a transparent and deep reddish brown solution was obtained. 2.8 Permeation experiments Permeation experiments were carried out with a H-type glass devices, as displayed in Fig. 2(i), 20 mL Li2S8 solution and 20 mL clear electrolyte were filled in the left and right of the devices, respectively. The Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP and pristine PP separators were assembled in the connector of the devices, singly. The whole process was performed in an Ar-filled glovebox. 2.9 Adsorption tests 20 mg Co-FeOOH microspheres and 20 mg MWCNTs were placed in 10 mL Li2S8 Solution for 24 h. The adsorption capacity of the Co-FeOOH microspheres and MWCNTs for Li2S8 was evaluated by testing the concentration of residual Li2S8 with a UV–vis spectro-photometer. The whole process was performed in an Ar-filled glovebox before the measurement of UV–vis spectra. 2.10 Symmetrical cell assembly and kinetic evaluation of polysulfides conversion The Co-FeOOH or MWCNTs electrodes were prepared by mixing Co-FeOOH or MWCNTs and PVDF (9:1 by weight) in N-methyl-2-pyrolidone (NMP) to form a homogeneous slurry. The slurry was then uniformly coated on the surface of the Al current collector and oven-dried at 60 °C for 12 h to remove the NMP. Then the coated Al foil was punched into pieces 12 mm in diameter. For the study of kinetic evaluation of polysulfides conversion, two counter electrodes (Co-FeOOH or MWCNTs electrodes) were assembled into a standard 2032 coin cell with a Celgard 2500 membrane as the separator, and 40 µL 0.5 M Li2S6 (prepared with a similar method of the aforementioned 5 mM Li2S8 Solution by control the stoichiometric ratio of sulfur and Li2S to 5:1) solution with 1.0 M LiTFSI and 1 wt% LiNO3 in DOL/DME (1:1 by volume) was used as electrolyte. The CV measurement of the symmetrical batteries were executed at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1 in the voltage rage of −0.8 to 0.8 V. 2.11 Li2S precipitation experiments The battery was assembled into a standard 2032 coin cell with a Celgard 2500 membrane as the separator, before-mentioned Co-FeOOH or MWCNTs electrodes as cathode and lithium foil used as anode. 20 µL 0.5 M Li2S8 solution with 1.0 M LiTFSI and 1 wt% LiNO3 in DOL/DME (1:1 by volume) was dropped on the side of Co-FeOOH or MWCNTs electrode and 20 µL blank electrolyte without Li2S8 was dropped on the Li foil. The batteries were firstly discharged galvanostatically at 0.112 mA to 2.06 V and then kept potentiostatically at 2.05 V until the current below 10−5 A. 3 Results and discussion The Co-doped FeOOH (hydroxy iron oxides) microspheres (Co-FeOOH) were prepared through a simple and facile one-step hydrothermal method, as shown in Scheme S1. The urchin-like microspheres with a mean size of about 5 µm which are consisted of numerous nanorods with a diameter of about 100 nm are observed from scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images in Fig. 1 (a and c). As depicted in Fig. 1(d), the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the urchin-like microspheres matches well with a α-FeOOH (goethite) standard pattern (JCPDS No. 29–0713), and there is no diffraction peak of the lattice Co in the XRD pattern resulted from the low content and small size of Co species (<5 nm) [37], indicating that doping with Co can not change the crystal structure of the α-FeOOH. Furthermore, the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image in Fig. 1(e) clearly confirms the urchin-like morphology. As shown in Fig. 1(f, g and i), the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of the urchin-like microspheres reveal a hierarchically layered structure of the nanorods and their lattice fringes with an average interplanar distance of 2.65 Å in keeping with the (130) lattice plane of α-FeOOH (2.69 Å). The slight difference of the lattice plane is due to partial substitution of Fe by Co [38]. In addition, a series of typical diffraction rings indexed to the (020), (110), (120) and (130) lattice planes of α-FeOOH can be observed by the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern in Fig. 1(j), solidly supporting the conclusion of the XRD analysis. The high-angle annular darkfield imaging (HAADF) scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) image and relevant elemental mappings display an uniform distribution of the Fe, O and Co elements in Co-FeOOH microspheres (Fig. 1(k)), which confirms the homogeneous Co doping. The specific surface area and pore structure of the Co-FeOOH microspheres are investigated by nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis within the relative pressure (P/P o) range of 0–1. As shown in Fig. 1(h), the isotherm is typical type-IV presenting that the N2 uptake is a steep rise of at very low P/P o, a H4-type hysteresis loop over 0.5 of P/P o and then a rapid increase at P/P o>0.9, which clearly reflects that the Co-FeOOH microspheres have a hierarchically porous structure of micro-/meso-/macropores corresponding to the pore size distribution curve in Fig. 1(l). The calculated Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (S BET), total pore volume (V total) and average pore diameter (D) are 76.35 m2 g−1, 0.2 cm3 g−1 and 8.92 nm, respectively. Accordingly, the hierarchically porous structure and large surface area of Co-FeOOH microspheres should be beneficial for fast lithium ions transfer, good permeation of electrolyte and effective anchoring of polysulfides [39]. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were carried out to further determine the atomic ratio and chemical composition of the Co-FeOOH microspheres. The XPS survey spectrum in Fig. S1(a) discloses the existence of Fe, Co, and O elements in the Co-FeOOH microspheres and exhibits the atomic ratio (Fe:Co:O) of about 1:0.2:1.9 similar to the ICP-MS result (approximate 1:0.2:2) in Table S2. For the spectrum of Fe 2p in Fig. S1(b), two dominating peaks together with two shake-up satellites (sat.) are observed at 712.8, 725.5, 719.2 and 732.6 eV which are assigned to Fe 2p 3/2, Fe 2p 1/2, Fe 2p 3/2 sat. and Fe 2p 1/2 sat. of Fe3+ in iron oxide, respectively. Two additional peaks at 710.8 and 724.4 eV could be assigned to Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2 of Fe3+ in Fe-O-Co bond, which is supported by the peak of Fe-O-Co bond at 529.8 eV in the O 1s spectrum (Fig. S1d) [40,41]. In the O 1s spectrum, another two peaks at 531.2 and 533.0 eV are attributed to Fe-O and Fe-OH bonds, respectively [42]. As shown in Fig. S1c, the Co 2p spectrum can be divided into four peaks at 781.7, 783.6, 787.0 and 790.7 eV which can be assigned to Co 2p 3/2 and satellite peak, respectively [43]. It is well known that the commercial PP separator as an inert isolated layer between cathode and anode is porous. For Li-S battery, such a porous structure not only can ensure a normal transportation of lithium ions, but also is unimpeded for the shuttling of dissolved polysulfides to anode. As has been noted, to directly coat the barrier layer on the commercial PP separator is one of most effective strategy to restrain the polysulfides shuttle. In diverse strategies of constructing the barrier layer, the vacuum filtration method is deemed to a facile, low-cost and controllable route [19]. Hence, the modified PP separator (Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP) is obtained by coating a Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs layer on the single side of the commercial PP separator (Celgard 2500) via the vacuum filtration of the dispersion of Co-FeOOH microspheres and MWCNTs (Scheme S1). As shown in Fig. 2(b) and Fig. S2(b), the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP possesses a dense surface without a large number of visible holes comparing with the pristine PP separator (Figs. 2(a) and S2a). The cross-sectional SEM image in Figs. 2(c) and S2(c) exhibits a uniform 3D network of the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs layer with a thickness of 22.2 µm and areal density of 0.6 mg cm−2. The corresponding elemental mappings in Figs. S3 and S4 further indicate a homogeneous distribution of Co-FeOOH microspheres and MWCNTs in the barrier layer. Good wettability of the separator to electrolyte is essential, which is beneficial for enhancing Li+ conductivity and reducing interface resistance. Fortunately, the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator with a contact angle (CA) of as low as 0° displays a better wettability than that of pristine PP separator (CA=19°) (insets of Fig. 2(a and b)). This result should be owing to plentiful hydrophilic groups and a high BET surface area of Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs composite (Fig. S5). In addition, the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs layer adheres well to the surface of the PP separator and is mechanically durable with an excellent flexibility. As shown in Fig. 2(d), after folded and refolded many times, the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator can recover completely without any delamination and cracking. Such an uniform porous 3D network is beneficial for storing organic liquid electrolyte, which can prevent an abnormal running caused by an evaporation of the electrolyte when the battery is under a high temperature. Actually, the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator delivers an electrolyte uptake (η) value of 132.8 ± 0.9% which is much higher than that of the pristine PP separator (74.3 ± 1.5%) (Fig. S6), clearly demonstrating an excellent electrolyte storing capability. When the batteries suffer from a thermal attack, a good thermal stability of the separator in dimensions can avoid a high risk of the internal short circuit, which is favorable for improving the safety of the batteries. As shown in Figs. 2(e) and S7(a), the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator can keep an original dimension at 120 and 140 °C, while the PP separator exhibits a thermal shrinkage of 5.6% and 15.5%, respectively. Further elevating the temperature to 160 °C, the thermal shrinkage of the PP separator is high to 50.1%, but the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator almost maintains an original dimension with a slightly thermal shrinkage of 11.3%. The results distinctly present that the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator possesses an excellent thermal dimensional stability, which is owe to a thermally stable of Co-FeOOH and MWCNTs (Fig. S7b and c). This superior thermotolerance could effectively prevent the internal short circuit of batteries arising from an increasing ambient temperature or/and a thermal effect during high charged/discharged rates applied. Furthermore, a high combustibility of the PP separator also leads to the safety problem in the Li-S battery. Accordingly, combustion tests of different separators are shown in Fig. 2(f and g). The pristine PP separator shows vigorous combustion with severe melt dripping and a lot of heat release and burns completely without any residue in the end, while the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator is observed to be a weaken inflammability and maintain a original morphology after being spontaneously extinguished. More specifically, a specific burning time (SBT) of the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator was calculated to be 306.4 ± 5.6 s g−1 and far below that of PP separator (586.6 ± 12.2 s g−1) (Fig. S8). Apparently, the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator has an excellent flame retardancy, which could afford an obviously improved safety for the Li-S battery. Benefiting from abundant transition metal elements and hydroxyl groups, the Co-FeOOH microspheres could be an ideal chemical anchor to capture polysulfides, which was verified by the density functional theory (DFT) calculation. The optimized structures of various polysulfides (Li2S, Li2S2, Li2S4, Li2S6, Li2S8) binding on the Co-FeOOH (110) surface are exhibited in Fig. 2(h). At the start of lithiation, the binding energy (E b) of Li2S8 on the Co-FeOOH (110) surface is −5.37 eV, and subsequently the E b values for Li2S6, Li2S4, Li2S2 and Li2S change to −7.12 eV, −8.91 eV, −7.69 eV and −6.78 eV as the lithiation process continues, respectively. Compared with prviously reported Fe-based [44] and Co-based [45] materials, the Co-FeOOH microspheres exhibit observably much higher binding energies for the diverse Li2S x (5 eV<|E b|< 9 eV ), indicating that the Co-FeOOH microspheres could be expected to endow the Li-S battery with excellent performance. Significantly, the |E b| value of Li2S4 is as high as 8.91 eV, which implies the existence of a catalytic conversion of polysulfides (vide infra). A permeation experiment was carried out to visually prove that the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs barrier layer on the PP separator can impede the polysulfides migration. In H-type glass cell, 20 mL of Li2S8 electrolyte solution (5 mM) and 20 mL of pure electrolyte were separated in left and right chambers of the cell by either the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs modified PP separator or pristine PP separator, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2(i), it can be clearly observed that the Li2S8 diffused gradually from left to right chamber in the cases of the pristine PP separator with prolonging the time. Conversely, only trace amounts of the Li2S8 penetrate through the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator after 72 h, demonstrating that the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs barrier layer can restrain the shuttling of soluble polysulfides effectively. By an adsorption test of polysulfides and the corresponding ultraviolet-visible (UV–vis) spectroscopy, the contribution of each compounds in the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator to capturing polysulfides was investigated. As exhibited in Fig. S9(a and c), after soaking for 24 h, the color of Li2S8 solution with MWCNTs is slightly faded, while the Li2S8 solution with Co-FeOOH microspheres turns into nearly colourless from deep yellow, indicating that the Co-FeOOH microspheres plays a dominant role in capturing the soluble polysulfides. The corresponding UV–vis spectra in Fig. S9(b) also provide a consistent result, that is, the solution with Co-FeOOH microspheres possesses a lowest intensity of characteristic peak of polysulfides. Except strong chemical anchor for the polysulfides, unimpeded Li-ion/electron transport and fast reaction kinetics are also indispensable for the high-performance Li-S battery. In order to quantitatively assess the transport ability of lithium ions and their contribution in charge transfer through the separators, the Li-ion transference number (t+ ) was measured by a potentiostatic polarization method on a symmetric coin cell assembled with either Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator or pristine PP separator and two Li foil electrodes. According to the Nyquist plots and polarization curves of the symmetric coin cells with DOL/DME electrolyte in Fig. S10a and b, a significant improvement of the t+ from 0.32 to 0.58 (Table S3) is obtained by modifying the pristine PP separator with the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs layer, reflecting an enhanced permeability of the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator for lithium ions which is beneficial to endow the Li-S battery with excellent performances, especially rate capability [46]. When Li2S8/DOL/DME electrolyte was used (Fig. S10c and d, and Table S3), the t+ of the cell with pristine PP separator is 0.57 whereas the one with the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator is up to 0.91, demonstrating that the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs layer can block efficiently the diffusion of polysulfides anions, which is in accord with the permeation experiment. In addition, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used to determine the charge transfer resistance (R ct) and the Li-ion conductivity (σ) of pristine PP and Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separators. As shown in Fig. S11 and Table S3, the R ct value of Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator simulated from a semicircular portion of the ESI curve is obviously lower (65.8 Ω) than that of pristine PP separator (182.4 Ω), meaning a better charge transfer kinetics at the interface between electrode and electrolyte due to high t+ value, excellent wettability of electrolyte and good conductivity of MWCNTs in the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs layer [47], which thus can contribute to an enhanced utilization of sulfur. Impedance plots of the symmetrical cells assembled by sandwiching the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator or pristine PP separator with two stainless steels are shown in Fig. S12, and the calculated Li-ion conductivity is listed in Table S3. For the pristine PP separator, the σ value is about 0.57 mS cm−1 considered as the contribution of the liquid electrolyte. Generally, to modify the PP separator by coatings often leads to a decrease of the σ value due to an impeded pathway of the Li-ion diffusion. Surprisingly, after introducing the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs layer, the modified separator acquires the significantly elevated σ value of as high as 1.44 mS cm−1, indicating that the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs layer greatly facilitated the Li-ion transport through the separator, which could lead to the improving rate performance. Correspondingly, the Li-ion diffusion coefficients (D Li+) were investegated via cyclic voltammograms (CVs) at various scan rates. As exhibited in Fig. S13(a and c), comparing with the pristine PP separator, the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator displays a better identity of the CV curves and a smaller voltage gap between oxidation and reduction peaks, reflecting a lower electrochemical polarization. According to the Randles-Sevick equation and the corresponding linear fitting curves of I p versus v 1/2 for each redox peak (anodic peak designated as a, cathodic peaks at high and low voltage designated as b and c, respectively) in Fig. S13(b and d), the calculated D Li+ of the Li-S batteries with either Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator or PP separator for the three peaks are summarized in Table S3. Significantly, three D Li+ values of the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator are considerably higher than those of PP separator. This result seems to be because the porous 3D network structure of the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs layer with large surface area can store more electrolyte and thus affords more conducive paths for the Li ions transport, in accordance with its high σ and low R ct. In order to achieve the reliable Li-S battery, the fast conversions of the sulfur in discharging process involving a series of liquid-liquid, liquid-solid, and solid-liquid reactions, is highly desired. According to previous report [48], the chronoamperometry was employed to probe a liquid-solid conversion, i.e., nucleation and growth of lithium sulfide (Li2S) on reactive surface. As shown in Fig. 3 (a and b) from potentiostatic discharge experiments, the Co-FeOOH microspheres present a much higher activity toward the nucleation and growth of Li2S (Li2S precipitation) corresponding to a higher precipitation current in comparison with that of pristine MWCNTs, which indicates that the Co-FeOOH microspheres can not only capture the LiPSs but also effectively facilitate their fast conversion to the insoluble Li2S during the discharging process [49]. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement was carried out to further study the liquid-liquid reaction of LiPSs on the surface of either Co-FeOOH microspheres or MWCNTs. As exhibited in Fig. 3(c), the Co-FeOOH microspheres symmetrical battery with Li2S6 possesses a higher redox current than that of the MWCNTs, while no obvious redox current for both of the symmetrical batteries without Li2S6 can be observed, solidly supporting that the Co-FeOOH microspheres provide an excellent contribution to immobilizing the LiPSs and catalytically accelerating their redox kinetics [50]. Likewise, the catalytic role of the Co-FeOOH microspheres for the redox kinetics of sulfur electrochemistry was demonstrated in actual Li-S batteries assembled with Li foil anode, Super-P/sulfur (SP/S) composite cathode (directly prepared through a simply mixing of sulfur powder and Super-P) with the sulfur content of about 70.01% (Fig. S14a) and different separators. The CV curve of the battery with Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator in Fig. 3(d) shows the classic redox peaks: two cathodic peaks at 2.25 and 2.04 V corresponding to the generation of soluble long-chain LiPSs (Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8) and insoluble short-chain lithium sulfides (Li2S2/Li2S), respectively, and one anodic peak at 2.45 V assigned to the subsequent oxidation of Li2S2/Li2S to elemental sulfur. Compared to the MWCNTs/PP and pristine PP separator, the battery with Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator possesses weaker polarization for all redox peaks and smaller voltage gap between oxidation and reduction peaks, suggesting the better kinetics due to effective adsorption and catalytic effect of the Co-FeOOH microspheres for polysulfides. For quantitative investigation, Tafel plots of the first reduction peak and the oxidation peak are presented in Fig. 3(e and f), respectively. The fitting Tafel slopes of the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP, MWCNTs/PP and PP separators in the first reduction are −0.034, −0.036 and −0.036 mV dec−1, respectively, while the values in the oxidation are 0.065, 0.099 and 0.146 mV dec−1, respectively. The lower Tafel slope of the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator reveals a high catalytic activity toward the reactions between polysulfides and sulfur/Li2S [51]. In view of the above discussions, good permeability, high Li-ion conductivity and catalytically accelerated redox reactions caused by the Co-FeOOH microspheres should endow the Li-S batteries with the excellent rate performance. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the battery with the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator delivers very high initial discharge specific capacities of 1625, 1311, 1127, 1008 and 936 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1 and 2 C (1 C = 1672 mA h g−1), respectively, exceeding 45%–73% and 81%–1165% of that of MWCNTs/PP and pristine PP, which reveals a high S utilization at various current densities. When sequentially switching from 2 C back to 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1 and 2 C, the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator can obtain the second initial capacities of 1652, 1247, 1086, 928 and 791 mA h g−1 corresponding to approximate 85%–100% of capacity restoration, indicating an excellent capacity reversibility at different C-rates. All charge-discharge curves of the batteries with either Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP or MWCNTs/PP separator at various rates exhibit two typical reduction plateaus assigned to the conversions of elemental S to long-chain LiPSs (upper plateau) and long-chain LiPSs to Li2S2/Li2S (lower plateau) (Figs. 4(b) and S15(a)), respectively, while only one reduction plateau for the PP separator battery is presented at the rates of above 0.5 C (Fig. S15b), also demonstrating that the introduction of Co-FeOOH and MWCNTs can effectively improve rate performance and electrochemical reversibility of the batteries. Moreover, discharge capacities of upper plateau (Q H), lower plateau (Q L) and their ratio (Q H/Q L) for different batteries under various current densities were compared in Fig. S15(c and d). The results show that the battery with Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator at all C-rates has a highest Q H as well as a lowest Q H/Q L, confirming that the Co-FeOOH microspheres afford the excellent contributions to suppress polysulfides migration and facilitate the reduction kinetics. In addition, the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator battery possesses the smallest potential gaps at all C-rates (Fig. 4(c)), proving its superior reaction kinetics. The long-term cyclic performance of batteries based on various separators was further assessed at 1 C. As shown in Fig. 4(d), the battery with the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator delivers an unparalleled initial discharge capacity of 1441 mA h g−1 and retains the discharge capacity of as high as 936 mA h g−1 with a capacity fading rate of 0.07% cycle−1 after 500 cycles, demonstrating an excellent cycling stability. In contrast, the discharge capacity of the battery with either pristine PP or MWCNTs/PP separator reduces dramatically from 551 to 142 mA h g−1 or from 919 to 391 mA h g− 1 after 400 cycles. Apparently, the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP based battery realizes more efficient utilization of the elemental S and sufficient suppression of the polysulfide shuttle, corresponding to a highest S utilization of 62.14% and a lowest capacity decay of 27.89% in comparison with both pristine PP and MWCNTs/PP separators after 400 cycles (Fig. 4(e)). The charge-discharge profiles of the batteries for different cycles at 1 C are presented in Fig. S16, and it can be found that the battery with the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator exhibits a longer voltage plateaus and lower polarization than the MWCNTs/PP and PP separators based batteries, indicating a better electrochemical reversibility and stability. Furthermore, we also prepared the FeOOH without doped Co which was confirmed by XRD (Fig. S17a). The FeOOH has an irregular morphology and consists of numerous nanorods and micron-sized lumps according to the SEM images (Fig. S17(b and c)), which should be unfavorable to the transportation of lithium ion during the charge/discharging process. In addition, the long-term cycling performance of the battery with FeOOH modified separator (FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP) at 1 C was studied (Fig. S17d and Table S5). In comparison, the initial capacity and retained capacity of the FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP-based battery are much lower than those of the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP-based battery, directly demonstrating that the Co doping into FeOOH is extremely significant for boosting the performance of the battery. Significantly, for the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP based battery, an initial discharge capacity of high to 827.29 mA h g−1 at 2 C is acquired, and a discharge capacity of 663.18 mA h g−1 with a capacity fading rate of low to 0.04% cycle−1 can be remained after 500 cycles (Fig. 4(f)). Considering the requirement of high-energy density in practical applications, high sulfur loading is also essential for Li-S batteries. As depicted in Fig. 4(g), the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP-based battery with sulfur loading of 3.1 mg cm−2 at 1 C delivers an initial capacity of 559.87 mA h g−1 after undergoing an activation of 5 cycles at 0.2 C, and subsequently a moderate discharge capacity of 516.68 mA h g−1 is obtained after 250 cycles, corresponding to an extremely low capacity fading rate of 0.031% cycle−1. All above results demonstrate that Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs layer with unimpeded Li-ion/electron transport, highly efficient capture and catalysis for polysulfides can greatly boost the utilization of S and inhibit the shuttle of polysulfides, which therefore contributes to extremely high discharge capacity and remarkable cycling stability of the Li-S batteries even at a high rate or a practical sulfur loading amount. Moreover, we also investigated the cycling performance of the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP-based battery with a lower areal loading of the functional layer. As shown in Fig. S18, although the battery with the areal loading of 0.3 mg cm−2 delivers a high initial discharge capacity of 1357.04 mA h g−1, the discharge capacity reduces dramatically to 504.48 mA h g−1 after 250 cycles with a capacity fading rate of 0.251% cycle−1, which indicates that reducing the areal loading of functional layer can result in the weakened suppression of the polysulfides shuttling. Besides, the electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio also greatly affects battery performance. As shown in Fig. S19, the batteries with 30 µL and 35 µL electrolyte corresponding to the E/S ratio of 16.7 and 19.4 µL mg−1 can deliver the retained discharge capacities of 694.5 and 1003.0 mA h g−1 after 100 cycle, respectively, signifying that the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator is still effective at lean-electrolyte condition to some extent. In order to have a further insight into the effect of the different separators on battery performances, the batteries with various separators after 200 charge/discharge cycling tests at 1 C were disassembled. As shown in Fig. 5 (a1 and a2) and (b1 and b2) in contrast to the smooth and intact fresh Li foil (Fig. S20a and b), the Li anode of the battery with either PP or MWCNTs/PP separator entirely suffered the severe corrosion and damage, leading to a very rough and jagged surface with a number of holes, cracks, Li dendrites and flake-like precipitates (Li2S/Li2S2), which should be attributed to polysulfides shuttle and subsequent side reactions on the Li anode surface [52]. However, the surface of the Li anode for the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP based battery is still smooth and without any Li dendrites or flake-like precipitates excepting some cracks (Fig. 5(a3 and b3)), indicating that the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator can provide an extrimely strong protection for the Li anode by impeding the shuttle of polysulfides and suppressing the growth of Li dendrites. In addition, for the PP and MWCNTs/PP based batteries (Fig. 5(c1 and c2)), a side of separator contacting with the lithium anode does not have the typical holes in fresh PP separator (Fig. S20c), but instead with a mass of granular/flake-like contaminations, which is unbeneficial for the Li-ion transferring and thus leads to the inferior cycle stability. Conversely, for the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP based battery (Fig. 5(c3)), the holes almost remain as-received after cycling, which means that the good Li-ion migration could be ensured during the long-term charge/discharge cycle. The corresponding elemental mapping and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) present a very strong S signal with the contents of high to 11.99 and 10.86 mol% in the cycled PP and MWCNTs/PP separators (Fig. S21a-d and Table S4), respectively, indicating the Li2S/Li2S2 deposition due to the polysulfides shuttle. But, for the cycled Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator, the S signal is much weaker (Fig. S21e and f), and the content of S is low to 2.99 mol% (Table S4), reconfirming the effective suppression of the polysulfides shuttle, which thus affords extremely high capacity and excellent cyclic stability. Furthermore, XPS analysis of the cycled Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator was performed to better understand the interaction between Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs modified layer and polysulfides. The C 1s spectrum in Fig. 5(d1) exhibits a series peaks located at 284.5, 285.7, 286.8, 288.7, 290.2 and 293.1 eV, corresponding to the bonds of CC/C=C, C-S, CO, OC=O, (-CF2CH2-)n and (-CF10CH8-)n, respectively. The existence of C-S reveals that the MWCNTs also make a contribution to restrain the shuttle of soluble polysulfides in certain degree [53]. As shown in the Fe 2p spectrum of Fig. 5(d2), excepting the typical peaks in the pristine Co-FeOOH microspheres (Fig. S1), two new peaks at 708.0 and 722.0 eV ascribed to Fe-S bond can be observed, indicating that the Co-FeOOH microspheres have a strong interaction with the sulfur-based species [44]. For the S 2p spectrum in Fig. 5(d3), the peaks at 167.3 eV and 169.4 eV can be assigned to the S-O bond of high valence sulfur species (e.g., polythionate and thiosulfate) which could be formed from the oxidation of polysulfides through Co-FeOOH microspheres catalysis during charge/discharge process or air exposure at the stage of XPS sample preparation [54]. The peaks at 162.6 and 163.9 eV are ascribed to Fe-S/terminal S (ST −1) and bridging S (SB 0), respectively, further confirming the interaction between Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs modified layer and sulfur-based species. In consideration of the practical applications, the safety and stability of Li-S batteries are demanded when employed at the extreme high/low temperature environment [55]. Unfortunately, the Li-S batteries commonly suffer from serious safety issue and inferior performance at high/low temperature. Actually, high temperature will result in thermal deformation of the PP separator and more serious shuttle effect, and the low temperature will slow down reaction kinetics of the sulfur conversions and lead to accumulation and loss of the LiPSs. To assess the contributions of the modified separators for the temperature-dependent performances of Li-S batteries, the cycling test at various temperatures were implemented. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), the battery with the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator presents an excellent cycling stability in a wide temperature range of −25 to 100 °C. As rising temperature, the discharge capacity first increased due to the enhanced diffusion of Li+ and then decreased because of the potential evaporation of low boiling points DOL/DME electrolyte [56]. Surprisingly, even at 100 °C, the average capacity and coulombic efficiency (CE) were high to 760 mA h g− 1 and 91%, respectively. On the contrary, at the same temperatures range, the pristine PP-based battery exhibited rapidly declined capacity and CE and even was disable to charge/discharge normally, which is mainly due to the slowed reaction kinetics at the low temperature and the separator deformation at the high temperature. Furthermore, the long-term cyclic tests at high and low temperatures adequately demonstrate the remarkable safety and stability of the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP based battery. As shown in Fig. 6(b), the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP based battery under 75 °C delivered a capacity of high to 862.3 mA h g−1 and a CE of 96.5% with a capacity fading rate of low to 0.018% cycle−1 (calculated based on the 5th cycle) after 100 cycles at 1 C, well above than those of PP (a retained capacity of 10.2 mA h g−1 and a CE of 75.8%). When the temperature dropped down to 0 °C (Fig. 6(c)), even −25 °C (Fig. 6(d)), namely the so-called “death line” of the common lithium batteries, the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP based battery delivered the excellent capacities of 608.4 and 420.6 mA h g−1 with stable CE of nearly 98 and 100% after 300 and 450 cycles at 1 C, respectively. The wider working temperature range reveals that the Co-FeOOH microspheres are very fascinating for expanding practical applications of Li-S batteries. In addition to the cycling stability problem, the shuttle effect-caused self-discharge behavior corresponding to the capacity loss for a certain storage period is another important challenge which the Li-S batteries face [57]. Generally, open-circuit voltage (OCV) of the fully charged battery is served for the quantitative assessment of its self-discharge behavior. As depicted in Fig. 6(e and f), the OCV of the battery for the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator remained an almost constant value of approximate 2.39 V after an elapsed time of 72 h at both 25 and 75 °C, indicating the significantly inhibited self-discharge. However, the OCV of the pristine PP-based battery sharply reduced to ~2.15 V from ~2.31 V, which reflects a conversion of soluble Li2S8/Li2S6 to semi-solid Li2S4 caused by the reaction of shuttled polysulfides with lithium anode [57]. For a proof-of-concept demonstration [58], the “SCU” (i.e., the abbreviation of Sichuan University) shaped LED panel assembled with 20 red light-emitting diodes was introduced to evaluate an operation status of the battery with either PP or Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator at different extreme temperatures. In terms of the pristine PP-based battery as shown in Fig. 6(g and i), the LED panel can be lighted up, but went out gradually in a relatively short time, especially at −25 °C. By contrast, the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP-based battery was able to enduringly power up the LED panel for over 60 and 30 min at 100 and −25 °C (Fig. 6(h and j)), respectively, implying its promising practical applications in the wider working temperature range. 4 Conclusions In summary, the urchin-like Co-doped FeOOH (Co-FeOOH) microspheres were first prepared to synergistically capture and catalytically convert polysulfides. By introducing the Co-FeOOH microspheres and MWCNTs composite as an interlayer onto one side of a commercial PP separator through a facile, low-cost and controllable vacuum filtration method, the thermotolerant and nonflammable multifunctional separator were constructed, and endowed the Li-S battery with superior electrochemical performance which was ascribed to strong anchoring for polysulfides, unimpeded Li-ion/electron transport and accelerating redox kinetics of sulfur conversion. Significantly, from −25 to 75 °C, the Li-S batteries with the Co-FeOOH/MWCNTs/PP separator can deliver excellent capability and outstanding cyclic stability at a high C-rate, which is rarely reported in the previously state-of-the-art works involving the modified separators. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries as extremely promising high-density energy storage devices have attracted extensive concern. However, practical applications of Li-S batteries are severely restricted by not only intrinsic polysulfides shuttle resulting from their concentration gradient diffusion and sluggish conversion kinetics but also serious safety issue caused by thermolabile and combustible polymer separators. Herein, it is presented for the first time that a robust and multifunctional separator with urchin-like Co-doped FeOOH microspheres and multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) as an interlayer simultaneously achieves to suppress polysulfides shuttle as well as improves thermotolerance and nonflammability of commercial PP separator. Accordingly, Li-S batteries with modified separator exhibit remarkable performance in a wide range temperatures of -25–100 °C. Typically, under 25 °C, ultrahigh initial capacities of 1441 and 827.29 mA h g−1 at 1 C and 2 C are delivered, and remained capacities of 936 and 663.18 mA h g−1 can be obtained after 500 cycles, respectively. At 0.1 C, the S utilization can reach up to 97%. Significantly, at 1 C, the batteries also deliver an excellent performance with remained capacities of high to 862.3, 608.4 and 420.6 mA h g−1 after 100, 300 and 450 cycles under 75, 0 and -25 °C, respectively. This work provides a new insight for developing stable and safe high-performance Li-S batteries.

coredata.dc:title: Multifunctional interlayer with simultaneously capturing and catalytically converting polysulfides for boosting safety and performance of lithium-sulfur batteries at high-low temperatures
